list.title: Question 1
list.content: Find the value of each of the following, giving your answer as an integer. - $\log_{10} 100$. [2] - $\log_{10} 50 + \log_{10} 2$. [2] - $\log_{10} 4 - \log_{10} 40$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.65em} \log_{10} 100 &= \log_{10} \big(10^2\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 2\log_{10} 10 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{10} 50 + \log_{10} 2 &= \log_{10} (50\cdot2) \hspace{2.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_{10} 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{10} 4 - \log_{10} 40 &= \log_{10} \bigg(\dfrac{4}{40}\bigg) \hspace{2.5em} \\[3pt]
  &= \log_{10} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{10}\bigg) \\[9pt]
  &= \log_{10} \big(10^{-1}\big) \\[16pt]
  &= (-1) \log_{10} 10 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Find the value of each of the following, giving your answer as an integer. - $\log_6 6$. [2] - $\log_6 9 + \log_6 4$. [2] - $\log_6 72 - \log_6 2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{\log_6 6 = 1}$
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_6 9 + \log_6 4 &= \log_6 (9\cdot4) \\[6pt]
  &= \log_6 36 \\[5pt]
  &= \log_6 \big(6^2\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 2\log_6 6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_6 72 - \log_6 2 &= \log_6 \bigg(\dfrac{72}{2}\bigg) \hspace{0.15em} \\[5pt]
  &= \log_6 36 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Let $\log_2 a = p$, $\log_2 b = q$, $\log_2 c = r$. Write down the following expressions in terms of $p$, $q$ and $r$. - $\log_2\Big(\dfrac{ab}{c}\Big)$ [2] - $\log_2\Big(\dfrac{a^2c}{b^3}\Big)$ [2] - $\log_a b$ [2]

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Consider
$a = \log_{63}64\times\log_{62}63\times\log_{61}62\times\dots\times\log_{2}3$.
Given that $a\in\mathbb{Z}$, find the value of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
a &= \log_{63}64\times\log_{62}63\times\log_{61}62\times\dots\times\log_{2}3 \\[11pt]
&= \dfrac{\log64}{\bcancel{\log63}}\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log63}}{\bcancel{\log62}}\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log62}}{\bcancel{\log61}}\times\cdots\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log3}}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{\log64}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{\log2^6}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{6\hspace{0.05em}\cancel{\log2}}{\cancel{\log2}} \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Let $p=\ln 2$ and $q = \ln 6$. Write down the following expressions in terms of $p$ and $q$. - $\ln 12$ [2] - $\ln 3$ [2] - $\ln 48$ [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of natural logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \ln 12 &= \ln (2\cdot6) \\[6pt]
  &= \ln 2 + \ln 6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= p + q}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of natural logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} \ln 3 &= \ln \bigg(\dfrac{6}{2}\bigg) \\[3pt]
  &= \ln 6 - \ln 2 \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= q - p}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of natural logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.6em} \ln 48 &= \ln \big(2^3\hspace{-0.2em}\cdot6\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 3\ln2 +  \ln 6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3p + q}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Solve the equation $\log_5 x - \log_5 4 = 2 + \log_5 3$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_5 x - \log_5 4 &= 2 + \log_5 3 \\[10pt]
\log_5 x - \log_5 4 &= \log_5 5^2 + \log_5 3 \\[8pt]
\log_5\dfrac{x}{4} &= \log_5 (5^2\hspace{-0.2em}\cdot3)  \\[5pt]
\log_5\dfrac{x}{4} &= \log_5 75 \\[5pt]
\dfrac{x}{4} &= 75 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{0.55em}\answer{x = 300}
$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Given that $\log_a 2 = 5$. - Find the exact value of $\log_a 32$. [2] - Find the exact value of $\log_{\sqrt{a}} 2$. [2] - Find the value of $a$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant figures. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_a 32 &= \log_a 2^5 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5 \log_a 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 5(5) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{\sqrt{a}} 2 &= \dfrac{\log 2}{\log \sqrt{a}} \hspace{2.1em} \\[2pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log 2}{\frac{1}{2}\log a} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\log_a 2 \\[12pt]
  &= 2(5) \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 10}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the definition of logarithm, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_a 2 &= 5 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  a^5 &= 2 \\[4pt]
  a &= 2^\frac{1}{5} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{a \approx 1.15} \hspace{0.8em}
  $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Solve the equation $\log_3 x - \log_3 5 = 1 + \log_3 4$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_3 x - \log_3 5 &= 1 + \log_3 4 \\[10pt]
\log_3 x - \log_3 5 &= \log_3 3 + \log_3 4 \\[8pt]
\log_3\dfrac{x}{5} &= \log_3 (3\hspace{-0.2em}\cdot4)  \\[5pt]
\log_3\dfrac{x}{5} &= \log_3 12 \\[5pt]
\dfrac{x}{5} &= 12 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{0.55em}\answer{x = 60}
$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Let $a = \log_5b$, where $b > 0$. Write down each of the following expressions in terms of $a$. - $\log_5b^4$ [2] - $\log_5 (25b)$ [2] - $\log_{25}b$ [2]

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Given that $\log_b 3 = 10$. - Find the exact value of $\log_b 81$. [2] - Find the exact value of $\log_{b^2} 3$. [2] - Find the value of $b$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant figures. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_b 81 &= \log_b 3^4 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &= 4 \log_b 3 \\[6pt]
  &= 4(10) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 40}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{b^2} 3 &= \dfrac{\log 3}{\log b^2} \hspace{2.1em} \\[3pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log 3}{2\log b} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log_b 3 \\[7pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(10) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the definition of logarithm, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_b 3 &= 10 \hspace{3.3em} \\[6pt]
  b^{10} &= 3 \\[4pt]
  b &= 3^\frac{1}{10} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b \approx 1.12} \hspace{0.6em}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: - Write the expression $4\ln 2 - \ln 8$ in the form of $\ln k$, where $k \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $4\ln 2 - \ln 8 = -\ln (2x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\ln 2 - \ln 8 &= \ln \big(2^4\big) - \ln 8 \\[12pt]
  &= \ln 16 - \ln 8 \\[6pt] 
  &= \ln\Big(\dfrac{16}{8}\Big) \\[9pt]
  & \answer{= \ln 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Replacing the left hand side of the equation with $\ln 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\ln 2 - \ln 8 &= -\ln (2x) \\[12pt]
  \ln 2  &= -\ln(2x) \hspace{2.2em} \\[12pt]
  -\ln 2 &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
  \ln \big(2^{-1}\big) &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
  2x &= 2^{-1} \\[12pt]
  2x &= \dfrac 1 2 \\[13pt]
  &\hspace{-0.525em} \answer{x = \dfrac{1}{4}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Solve the equation $\log_3(x^2-4x+4) = 1 + \log_3(x-2)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_3(x^2-4x+4) &= 1 + \log_3(x-2) \\[6pt]
\log_3(x^2-4x+4) &= \log_3 3 + \log_3(x-2) \\[6pt]
\log_3(x^2-4x+4) &= \log_3(3x-6) \\[6pt]
x^2-4x+4 &= 3x-6 \\[6pt]
x^2-7x+10 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(x-2)(x-5) &= 0 \\[7pt]
x-5 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 > 0$}] \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x=5} \hspace{3.15em}
$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Find the value(s) of $x$ when
$27^{x+2} = \left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)^{2x+4}$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
27^{x+2} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)^{2x+4} \\[3pt]
\left(3^3\right)^{x+2} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{3^2}\right)^{2x+4} \\[9pt]
3^{3x+6} &= 3^{-4x-8} \\[16pt]
3x+6 &= -4x-8 \\[16pt]
7x &= -14 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x = -2} \hspace{0.5em}
$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Solve the equation $\log_2(x^2-2x+1) = 1 + \log_2(x-1)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_2(x^2-2x+1) &= 1 + \log_2(x-1) \\[6pt]
\log_2(x^2-2x+1) &= \log_2 2 + \log_2(x-1) \\[6pt]
\log_2(x^2-2x+1) &= \log_2(2x-2) \\[6pt]
x^2-2x+1 &= 2x-2 \\[6pt]
x^2-4x+3 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(x-1)(x-3) &= 0 \\[7pt]
x-3 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{$x\neq1$, since $\log_20$}]\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x = 3} \hspace{3.15em}
$$

list.title: Question 15
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_2 8 &= \log_2 \big(2^3\big) \\[6pt]
    &= 3\log_2 2 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_5\Big(\dfrac{1}{25}\Big) &= \log_5\big(5^{-2}\big) \hspace{1.4em} \\[6pt]
    &= (-2)\log_5 5 \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= -2}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_9 3 &= \dfrac{\ln 3}{\ln 9} \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{\ln 3}{\ln \big(3^2\big)} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\ln 3}{2\ln 3} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_2 8 + \log_5\Big(\dfrac{1}{25}\Big) + \log_9 3 &= \log_{16} x \hspace{6.5em} \\[6pt]
  3 + (-2) + \dfrac{1}{2} &= \log_{16} x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{2} &= \log_{16} x \\[10pt]
  16^{3/2} &= x \\[14pt]
  4^3 & = x \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.7em} \answer{x = 64}
  $$

list.title: Question 16
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_3 81 &= \log_3\big(3^4\big) \\[6pt]
    &= 4\log_3 3 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_2\Big(\dfrac{1}{8}\Big) &= \log_2\big(2^{-3}\big) \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
    &= (-3)\log_2 2 \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= -3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_{25} 5 &= \dfrac{\ln 5}{\ln 25} \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{\ln 5}{\ln \big(5^2\big)} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\ln 5}{2\ln 5} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_3 81 + \log_2\Big(\dfrac{1}{8}\Big) + \log_{25} 5 &= \log_{9} x \hspace{7.6em} \\[6pt]
  4 + (-3) + \dfrac{1}{2} &= \log_{9} x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{2} &= \log_{9} x \\[10pt]
  9^{3/2} &= x \\[14pt]
  3^3 & = x \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.4em} \answer{x = 27}
  $$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Solve $\log_6(x) + \log_6(x-5) = 2$, for $x > 5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_6(x) + \log_6(x-5) &= 2 \\[6pt]
\log_6(x(x-5)) &= \log_6 6^2 \\[5pt]
\log_6 (x^2-5x) &= \log_6 36 \\[5pt]
x^2-5x &= 36 \\[5pt]
x^2 - 5x - 36 &= 0 \\[6pt]
(x + 4)(x - 9) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x - 9 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x + 4 > 0$}]\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x = 9} \hspace{1.6em}
$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Find the values of $x$ when
$25^{x^2-2x} = \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2}$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
25^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2} \\[3pt]
\left(5^2\right)^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{5^3}\right)^{4x+2} \\[9pt]
5^{2x^2-4x} &= 5^{-12x-6} \\[16pt]
2x^2 - 4x &= -12x-6 \\[16pt]
x^2 - 2x &= -6x - 3 \\[16pt]
x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[17pt]
(x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{3.45em}\answer{x = -3,-1}
$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Solve the equation $9^x + 2\cdot3^{x+1} = 1$.
list.markScheme:
If we substitute $y = 3^x$ in the equation $9^x + 2\cdot3^{x+1} = 1$, we
have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(3^x\right)^2 + 6\cdot3^x - 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
y^2 + 6y - 1 &= 0\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the quadratic formula, we
get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{13em} y &= \dfrac{-6 + \sqrt{6^2 - 4(1)(-1)}}{2(1)} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $y = 3^x > 0$}] \\[4pt]
&= \dfrac{-6 + 2\sqrt{10}}{2} \\[12pt]
&= -3 + \sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the properties of
logarithms, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
3^x &= -3 + \sqrt{10} \hspace{2.6em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{0.3em} \answer{x = \log_3(-3 + \sqrt{10})}
$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content: Find the value of - $\log_5 75 - \log_5 3$; [2] - $25^{\log_5 8}$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_5 75 - \log_5 3 &= \log_5\Big(\dfrac{75}{3}\Big) \hspace{3.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_5 25 \\[10pt]
  &= \log_5\big(5^2\big) \\[12pt]
  &= 2 \log_5 5 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  25^{\log_5 8} &= \big(5^2\big)^{\log_5 8} \\[8pt]
  &= 5^{2\log_5 8} \\[6pt]
  &= 5^{\log_5 (8^2)} \\[7pt]
  &= 5^{\log_5 64} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 64}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 21
list.content: Find the value of - $\log_7 98 - \log_7 2$; [2] - $49^{\log_7 6}$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_7 98 - \log_7 2 &= \log_7\Big(\dfrac{98}{2}\Big) \hspace{3.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_7 49 \\[10pt]
  &= \log_7\big(7^2\big) \\[12pt]
  &= 2 \log_7 7 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  49^{\log_7 6} &= \big(7^2\big)^{\log_7 6} \\[8pt]
  &= 7^{2\log_7 6} \\[6pt]
  &= 7^{\log_7 (6^2)} \\[7pt]
  &= 7^{\log_7 36} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 36}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Solve the equation $15^{4a} = 81^{a+2}$ for $a$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 3$ and $\ln 5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
15^{4a} &= 81^{a+2} \\[10pt]
(3\cdot5)^{4a} &= 3^{4(a+2)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot5^{4a} &= \cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot3^8 \\[10pt]
5^{4a} &= 3^8 \\[10pt]
\ln 5^{4a} &= \ln 3^8 \\[10pt]
4a \ln 5 &= 8\ln 3\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{2.25em}\answer{a = \dfrac{2\ln 3}{\ln 5}}
$$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Consider $f(x) = \log_k(8x-2x^2)$, for $0 < x < 4$, where $k > 0$.
The equation $f(x) = 3$ has exactly one solution. Find the value of $k$.
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation $f(x) = 3$ in the form $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$,
we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} \log_k(8x-2x^2) &= 3 \\[6pt]
8x-2x^2 &= k^3 \\[6pt]
0 &= 2x^2 - 8x + k^3\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the quadratic function
$q(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + k^3$ has two equal roots.
Therefore we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.1em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &= 0 \\[6pt]
(-8)^2 - 4(2)(k^3) &= 0 \hspace{3em}  [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
64 - 8k^3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
8 - k^3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
k^3 &= 8 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{3.3em} \answer{k=2}
$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Solve $\log_{\sqrt{3}}(\sin x) - \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\cos x) = 1$, for
$0 < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$.
list.markScheme:
We have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7f375b41-33b9-4587-922a-02c76aab5a0d/images/2bc01858-af34-4ec1-bef2-2c845c61c439/eea28ea6dc26969cf5c008612e865ae5046a04ef.svg)


Using the properties of logarithms and the right triangle above, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.1em} \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\sin x) - \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\cos x) &= 1 \\[6pt]
\log_{\sqrt{3}}\hspace{-0.2em}\Big(\dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}\Big) &= 1 \\[8pt]
\log_{\sqrt{3}}(\tan x) &= 1 \\[10pt]
\tan x &= \sqrt{3} \\[10pt]
x &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} + n\pi \hspace{2.3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}$}] \\[6pt]
x &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} + 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \pi\hspace{-0.05em}/2$}] \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{2.1em} \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{3}}
$$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Solve the equation $14^{6x} = 64^{x+3}$ for $x$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 2$ and $\ln 7$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
14^{6x} &= 64^{x+3} \\[10pt]
(2\cdot7)^{6x} &= 2^{6(x+3)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot7^{6x} &= \cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot2^{18} \\[10pt]
7^{6x} &= 2^{18} \\[10pt]
\ln 7^{6x} &= \ln 2^{18} \\[10pt]
6x\ln 7 &= 18\ln 2\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{1.9em}\answer{x = \dfrac{3\ln 2}{\ln 7}}
$$

list.title: Question 26
list.content: The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $\ln x^9$, $\ln x^3$, $\ln x$, for $x > 0$. - Find the common ratio. [3] - Hence, solve $\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x = 27$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 9\ln x$ and $u_2 = 3\ln x$.
Hence the common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\ln x}{9\ln x} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The $n$th term of the geometric sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_n &= u_1r^{n-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 9\ln x\bigg(\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg)^{n-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 3^{3-n}\ln x\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $S_{\infty} = 27$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} &= 27 \hspace{2.8em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{9\ln x}{1 - 1/3} &= 27 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{27\ln x}{3-1} &= 27 \\[12pt]
  \ln x &= 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = e^2}
  $$

list.title: Question 27
list.content: The equation $e^{2x} - 12e^x = -32$ has two solutions, $x_1$ and $x_2$. - Find the value of $x_1$ and the value of $x_2$.[5] A second equation, $2\left(\log_{\,9}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\log_{\,9}x - 2\log_{\,3}x = -6$, also has two solutions, $x_3$ and $x_4$. - - Show that this second equation can be expressed as $$ \begin{align*} \left(\log_{\,3}x\right)^2 -5\log_{\,3}x + 6 = 0 \end{align*} $$ - Hence find the value of $x_3$ and the value of $x_4$. [7] - Given that $x_1 + x_2 = a(x_3 + x_4)$, find the value of $a$. Give your answer in the form $b\ln c$, where $b,c \in \mathbb{R}$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- The equation can be written as a quadratic in $e^x$:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(e^x\right)^2 - 12e^x + 32 = 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The equation can then be factorised:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(e^x - 4\right)\left(e^x - 8\right) = 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From the first bracket, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  e^x - 4 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  e^x &= 4 \\[8pt]
  x &= \ln 4 \\[8pt]
  &= 2\ln 2
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And from the second bracket,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  e^x - 8 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  e^x &= 8 \\[8pt]
  x &= \ln 8 \\[8pt]
  &= 3\ln 2
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence, $x_1 = 2\ln 2$ and $x_2 = 3\ln 2$.
- 
  - We are asked to write the second equation in terms of $\log_{\,3}x$, and currently the equation is expressed in terms of $\log_{\,3}x$ and $\log_{\,9}x$. Using the formula for changing the base, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,9}x &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{\log_{\,3}9} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{\log_{\,3}3^2} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{2\log_{\,3}3} \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,9}x &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log_{\,3}x
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Substituting this expression into our original equation, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    2\left(\log_{\,9}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\log_{\,9}x - 2\log_{\,3}x &= -6 \\[8pt]
    2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 2\log_{\,3}x &= -6 \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-10em}\tcbhighmath{\left(\log_{\,3}x\right)^2 - 5\log_{\,3}x + 6 = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - The equation can be factorised as follows:

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \left(\log_{\,3}x - 2\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x - 3\right) = 0
    \end{align*}
    $$

    From the first bracket, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,3}x - 2 &= 0 \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,3}x &= 2 \\[8pt]
    x &= 9
    \end{align*}
    $$

    And from the second bracket,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,3}x - 3 &= 0 \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,3}x &= 3 \\[8pt]
    x &= 27
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence, $x_3 = 9$ and $x_4 = 27$.

- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x_1 + x_2 &= a(x_3 + x_4) \\[8pt]
  2\ln 2 + 3\ln 2 &= a(9+27) \\[8pt]
  5\ln 2 &= 36a \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{a = \dfrac{5}{36}\ln 2}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 28
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a + b\log_4 7 + 60\log_{8} 14 &= 0 \\[13pt]
a + \dfrac{b\ln 7}{2\ln 2} + \dfrac{60\ln 14}{3\ln 2} &= 0 \\[9pt]
a\ln 2 + \dfrac{b}{2}\ln 7 + 20\ln (2\cdot7) &= 0 \\[9pt]
a\ln 2 + \dfrac{b}{2}\ln 7 + 20(\ln 2 + \ln 7) &= 0 \\[9pt]
(a + 20)\ln 2 + \bigg(\dfrac{b}{2}+20\bigg)\ln 7 &= 0\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get
$\answer{a = -20}$
and  $\answer{b = -40}$

list.title: Question 29
list.content: The first three terms of an infinite sequence, in order, are $2\ln x,\,\, q\ln x,\,\, \ln \sqrt{x}\,\,\, \text{ where $\ x > 0$.} $ First consider the case in which the series is geometric. - - Find the possible values of $q$. - Hence or otherwise, show that the series is convergent. [3] - Given that $q>0$ and $S_\infty=8\ln{3}$, find the value of $x$. [3] Now suppose that the series is arithmetic. - - Show that $q=\dfrac{5}{4}$. - Write down the common difference in the form $m\ln x$, where $m \in \mathbb{Q}$. [4] - Given that the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence is $\ln \sqrt{x^5}$, find the value of $n$. [8]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Given that the sequence is geometric, we have for the common ratio

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q\ln x}{2\ln x} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_3}{u_2} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\ln \sqrt{x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\ln {x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{1}{2q} \\[8pt]
    q^2 &= 1 \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.49em}\tcbhighmath{q= \pm 1}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $r=\dfrac{q}{2}$, and $q= \pm 1$, we have $r = \pm \dfrac{1}{2}$. Hence $|r| < 1$.
    $\answer{\text{In both cases the series converges.}}$

- Given that $q>0$, $r = \dfrac{1}{2}$.
  Using the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric sequence, we~get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{1-\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= 4\ln x \\[10pt]
  2\ln 3 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 3^2 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 9 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-0.54em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - First we find the common difference $d$ as follows

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_2 - u_1\\[10pt]
    d &= q\ln x - 2\ln x \\[10pt]
    d &= (q-2)\ln x
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_3 - u_2\\[10pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln\sqrt{x} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln x^{1/2} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &=  \dfrac{1}{2}\ln x - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2} - q\bigg)\ln x \\[8pt]
    q-2 &= \dfrac{1}{2}-q \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{1}{2} + 2 \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{5}{2} \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{q = \dfrac{5}{4}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $d = (q-2)\ln x$ and $q = \dfrac{5}{4}$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= \left(\dfrac{5}{4}-2\right)\ln x \\[10pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{d = -\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- Using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_n &= \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) \\[8pt]
  \ln \sqrt{x^5} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(2\hspace{0.1em}(2\ln x) + (n-1)\left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x \right)\right) \\[8pt]
  \ln x^{5/2} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(\left(4\ln x + \left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\right)(n-1)\ln x\right) \right) \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{5}{2}\ln x &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right)\ln x \\[8pt]
  5 &= n\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right) \\[8pt]
  5 &= 4n - \dfrac{3n(n-1)}{4} \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n(n-1) \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n^2 + 3n \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -19n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -15n -4n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n(n-5) - 4(n-5) &= 0 \\[8pt]
  (3n-4)(n-5) &= 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The solutions to the quadratic equation are $n=\dfrac{4}{3}$ and $n=5$.
  Since $n$ must be an integer, we have $\answer{n = 5}$

list.title: Question 30
list.content: - Show that $\log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) = \log_4 \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7}$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $\log_4(\sqrt{10}\cos x) = \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7)$, for $0 < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$.[5]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) &= \dfrac{\log_4(\cos 2x + 7)}{\log_4 16} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log_4(\cos 2x + 7)}{2\log_4 4} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log_4(\cos 2x + 7) \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= \log_4 \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7}} \hspace{2.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the double angle formula for cosine, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.75em} \log_4(\textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x) &= \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) \\[14pt]
  \log_4(\textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x) &= \log_4 \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7} \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \hspace{3em} \\[14pt]
  \textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x &= \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7} \\[14pt]
  10\cos^2 x &= \cos 2x + 7 \\[14pt]
  10\cos^2 x &= (2\cos^2x - 1) + 7  \\[14pt]
  8\cos^2 x &= 6 \\[10pt]
  \cos^2 x &= \dfrac{3}{4} \\[4pt]
  \cos x &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \pi\hspace{-0.05em}/2$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{6}} \hspace{1em}
  $$

list.title: Question 31
Question 32
list.content: The arithmetic sequence has the sixth term of $u_6=\ln{2}$ and the eighth term of $u_8=\frac{3}{2}\ln{4}$. - - Show the common difference is $\ln2$. - Find $u_1$. - Hence, show that the sum of $n$ terms is given by $S_n=\left(n^2-9n\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}} $. Where $n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$. [5] A new function, $f(x)$, is formed using $S_n$ with the discrete variable $n$ being replaced with the continuous variable $x$, such that $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence $f(x)=\left(x^2-9x\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}}$. - - Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of $f(x)$. - Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, identify the axis of symmetry and any axis intercepts. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/5f674790-b5af-473c-b8d4-3f746b96c744/q1037.png) - Hence or otherwise, find the minimum value of $S_n$ in the form $a\ln b$. Where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ [5] Consider the linear function $g(x)=(6-3x)\ln {\sqrt 2}$. - - Solve $f(x)=g(x)$. - Hence, solve the inequality $f(x)[5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - As the sequence is arithmetic we can write $u_8=u_6+2d$. Hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \tfrac{3}{2}\ln{4}&=\ln{2}+2d \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        2d&=3\ln{(\sqrt{4})}-\ln2\\
        2d&=2\ln{2}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\ln2}\hspace{2.525em} \text{...as required} \tag*{\textbf{AG}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We can use $u_6$ to find the first term

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        u_6&=u_1+5d\\
        \ln2&=u_1+5\ln2\\
        u_1&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-4\ln2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Using the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence we can write

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        S_n&=\frac{n}{2}\left(2\times -4 \ln2 +(n-1)\times \ln2\right) \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        &=\frac{n^2}{2}\ln2-\frac{9n}{2}\ln2\\
        &=\frac{\ln2}{2}\left(n^2-9n\right) \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\left(n^2-9n\right)\ln{\sqrt{2}}} \hspace{2.525em} \text{...as required} \tag*{\textbf{AG}}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- 
  - Using the axis of symmetry formula, we can write

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x&=-\frac{-9\ln{\sqrt{2}}}{2\ln{\sqrt{2}}}\\
        &\hspace{-0.525em}\answer{x=\tfrac{9}{2}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Here is the sketch of $f(x)$ with the desired features identified.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/ff26f159-934a-404d-946c-88a7dab4de40/a1037-1.png)


    $\answer{\text{Correct intercepts}}$ A1 and $\answer{\text{axis of symmetry}}$ A1.
  - Using the symmetry of $f(x)$ we can identify the minimum value(s) of $f(x)$ which has integer $x$ coordinates.
    Both points are equidistant from the axis of symmetry and they represent the minimum value of $S_n$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/b53d4797-3cc2-48db-9678-27e521c1ec16/a1037-2.png)


    We can use the $x-$value from the graph to pick either $n=4$ or $n=5$ as both will yield the same minimum value. This solution will pick $n=4$, hence, the minimum value of $S_n$ is

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        S_4&=\left(4^2-9(4)\right)\frac{\ln2}{2}\\
        &=-20\frac{\ln2}{2}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-10\ln2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    \end{align*}
    $$


- 
  - Equate the RHS of each function

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \left(x^2-9x\right)\ln {\sqrt 2}&=(6-3x)\ln {\sqrt 2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Cancel out the factor $\ln {\sqrt 2}$ and solve for $x$

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x^2-9x&=6-3x\tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\
        0&=x^2-6x-6
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We can solve this by completing the square.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        (x-3)^2-9-6&=0\\
        x-3&=\pm\sqrt{15}\\
        x&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3\pm\sqrt{15}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}   
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - By making a rough sketch of $g(x)$ on the graph we can solve the inequality\
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/e5de3f5e-73f3-4a69-a581-b579611281ae/a1037-3.png)


    We can identify the region the $f(x)<g(x)$. Hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        &\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3-\sqrt{15}<x<3+\sqrt{15}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - $n$ must be a positive integer and lie entirely within the region identified in part (c)(ii).
    We know that $\sqrt{9}<\sqrt{15}<\sqrt{16}$, hence we can identify the minimum and maximum values of $n$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    The minimum value must be an integer larger than $3-\sqrt{15}$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        -1<3-\sqrt{15}<0
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The minimum value of $n$ is $1$.
    Similarly, the maximum value must be an integer smaller than $3+\sqrt{15}$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        6<3+\sqrt{15}<7
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The maximum value of $n$ is $6$.
    Hence
$\answer{1\leq n\leq 6}$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$

list.title: Question 33
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we rewrite the given equations as
follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_5 5 + \log_5 x^2 &= \log_5 7y \\[6pt]
\log_5 5x^2 &= \log_5 7y \\[6pt]
5x^2 &= 7y \hspace{5em}{(1)} \\[6pt]
\log_7 (6x-1) &= 1 + \log_7 y \\[6pt]
\hspace{2.75em} \log_7 (6x-1) &= \log_7 7 + \log_7 y \\[6pt]
\log_7 (6x-1) &= \log_7 7y \\[6pt]
6x - 1 &= 7y \hspace{5em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the equations (1) and (2),
we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
5x^2 &= 6x - 1 \\[6pt]
5x^2 - 6x + 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
(5x - 1)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x &= \dfrac{1}{5} \text{ or } x = 1 \end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $x = \dfrac{1}{5}$ into the equation (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
5 \left(\dfrac{1}{5} \right)^2 &= 7y \hspace{2.5em}\\[12pt] 
\dfrac{1}{5} &= 7y \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{1}{35}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $x = 1$ into the
equation (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
5(1)^2  &= 7y \\[12pt] 
5 &= 7y \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{5}{7}\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the solutions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\hspace{-2.15em}\answer{x = \dfrac{1}{5}, \, y = \dfrac{1}{35}} \\[12pt]
& \hspace{-1.9em}\answer{x = 1, \,\, y = \dfrac{5}{7}}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 34
list.content: The first two terms of an infinite geometric sequence, in order, are $$ 3\log_3x,\,\, 2\log_3x,\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common ratio, $r$. [2] - Show that the sum of the infinite sequence is $9\log_3 x$. [3] The first three terms of an arithmetic sequence, in order, are $$ \log_3x,\,\, \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3},\,\, \log_3\dfrac{x}{9},\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common difference $d$, giving your answer as an integer. [3] Let $S_6$ be the sum of the first $6$ terms of the arithmetic sequence. - Show that $S_6 = 6\log_3 x - 15$. [3] - Given that $S_6$ is equal to one third of the sum of the infinite geometric sequence, find $x$, giving your answer in the form $a^p$ where $a,p \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2\log_3 x}{3\log_3 x} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{2}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1 - 2/3} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1/3} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 9\log_3x} \hspace{5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.9em} d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3} - \log_3x \\[6pt]
  &= (\cancel{\log_3x} - \log_33) - \cancel{\log_3x} \hspace{0.5em} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} S_6 &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2u_1 + (6-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2(\log_3 x) + (6-1)(-1)) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2\log_3 x - 5) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 6\log_3 x - 15}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $S_6 = \dfrac{1}{3}S_{\infty}$ for $x$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= \dfrac{1}{3}(9\log_3x) \hspace{3.6em} \\[8pt]
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= 3\log_3x \\[12pt]
  3\log_3x &= 15 \\[12pt]
  \log_3x &= 5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = 3^5} \hspace{2.5em}
  $$

list.title: Question 35
list.content: - Show that $\log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} = \log_4 (3-\cos 2x)$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $\log_4 (3\sin x) \hspace{0.15em}+\hspace{0.15em} \dfrac{1}{4} = \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}$, for $0 \hspace{-0.05em}<\hspace{-0.05em} x \hspace{-0.05em}<\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{\pi}{2}$.[5]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} &= \dfrac{\log_4 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}}{\log_4 2} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log_4 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}}{\frac{1}{2}\log_4 4} \\[10pt]
  &= 2 \log_4 \hspace{-0.1em}\sqrt{3-\cos 2x} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\log_4 4 = 1$}] \\[18pt]
  &\answer{= \log_4(3-\cos 2x)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_4 (3\sin x) + \dfrac{1}{4} &= \textstyle \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} \\[4pt]
  \hspace{3.5em} \log_4 (3\sin x) + \dfrac{1}{4}\log_4 4 &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[7pt]
  \textstyle \log_4 (3\sin x) + \log_4\sqrt{2} &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{since $\textstyle 4^{1/4} = \sqrt{2}$}\hspace{0.05em}] \\[10pt]
  \textstyle \log_4 (3\sqrt{2}\sin x)\hspace{-0.1em} &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \\[10pt]
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 3-\cos 2x \qref{(1)} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $0 < x < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 3 - (1 - 2\sin^2 x) \hspace{1.3em} [\text{by double angle identity}] \\[9pt]
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 2 + 2\sin^2 x \\[9pt]
  \textstyle 2\sin^2 x - 3\sqrt{2}\sin x + 2 &= 0 \hspace{2.1em} [\text{rearranging terms to form quadratic}] \\[9pt]
  \sin x &= \dfrac{3\sqrt{2} \pm \sqrt{18-4\cdot2\cdot2}}{4} \\[9pt] 
  \sin x &= \dfrac{3\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{2}}{4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\sin x \neq \sqrt{2}$}] \\[9pt] 
  \sin x &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{4}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \textstyle \frac{\pi}{2}$}]
  $$

list.title: Question 36
list.content: Prove that if the sum of the digits of a 4-digit number is divisible by 3, then the four-digit number is also divisible by 3.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ be a four-digit number such that

$$
\begin{align*}
    n=a_3a_2a_1a_0
\end{align*}
$$

where

$$
\begin{align*}
    a_3&=m \times 10^3\\
    a_2&=p\times10^2\\
    a_1&=r\times 10^1\\
    a_0&=s\times 10^0
\end{align*}
$$

$m,p,r,s\in\mathbb{Z^+}$ and $0 \leq m,p,r,s\leq9$ and $m\neq0$.
We can therefore rewrite $n$ as:

$$
\begin{align*}
n=m\times10^3+p\times10^2+r\times10^1+s\times10^0\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}
\end{align*}
$$

Because the sum of the digits is divisible by three, we know that

$$
\begin{align*}
    m+p+r+s=3k\hspace{1em}(k\in\mathbb{Z^+})
    \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}\\
\end{align*}
$$

We want to get that $3k$ into our equation for $n$ above as it is clearly divisible by 3, so we will rearrange to isolate for $s$:

$$
\begin{align*}
    s=3k-m-p-r
\end{align*}
$$

Substituting this into the equation for $n$:

$$
\begin{align*}
    n&=m\times10^3+p\times10^2+r\times10^1+3k-m-p-r
    \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}\\[6pt]
    n&=m\times10^3-m+p\times10^2-p+r\times10^1-r+3k\\[6pt]
    n&=m(1000-1)+p(100-1)+r(10-1)+3k\\[6pt]
    n&=999m+99p+9r+3k \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}\\[6pt]
    n&=3(333m+33p+3r+k)\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}\\[6pt]
    &\hspace{-0.5em}n \text{ is divisible by 3}\\[6pt]
\end{align*}
$$

Hence the four-digit number is also divisible by $3$.
